quote.#text: Everett McKinley Dirksen and Marigold Day

official-title.#text: Expressing support for designation of September 6, 2014, as

sponsor.#tail: submitted the following resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text: That

quote.#text: Everett McKinley Dirksen and Marigold Day

text.#text: supports the designation of

designates and adopts the flower commonly known as the Marigold, of the genus Tagetes, as the
			 floral emblem of

Whereas the great Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen of Pekin, Illinois, has passed from the halls of
			 the United States Capitol;
Whereas the current Members of
Whereas, upon the passing of Senator Dirksen, his contemporaries and peers stated that—
Senator Dirksen—
provided sage advice and counsel and wholehearted wisdom;

provided support that made the civil rights legislation of the 1960s a fact rather than a dream
			 during that decade; and
was known as an American who cultivated the chivalric virtues of public life, such as—
a love of combat in statesmanship;
a high sense of honor;
a practical acceptance of the standards of party loyalty; and
the acceptance of political life as a game to be played according to the rules; and

when Senator Dirksen spoke, the country listened, and his eloquence was a source of national
			 strength;

Whereas Senator Dirksen found himself wedded to the flower commonly known as the Marigold, of the
			 genus Tagetes, the rugged, robust, bright, and stately flower that is
			 somehow able to resist the onslaught of
			 insects while taking in stride extreme changes in temperature, fighting
			 back the scorching sun in summer and the chill of early spring evenings;

Whereas the peoples of the world have from time immemorial adopted emblems for their institutions
			 that represent their virtues;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has adopted emblems to represent to the
			 world the virtues of

text.#text: Whereas, from time to time, the
Whereas the Mace of the House of Representatives is one of the oldest symbols of

Whereas the Seal of the Senate represents the 13 original colonies with a shield comprised of 13
			 stars and 13 vertical stripes and a scroll inscribed with
Whereas the Seal of the Senate also includes—
an olive branch symbolizing peace;
an oak branch symbolizing strength;
a red liberty cap representing freedom; and
crossed fasces representing authority;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
more
			 appropriately as an emblem than does any other flower;

text.#text: Whereas the Marigold represents the character of the
Whereas the Marigold is a native of North America and nowhere else in the world;
Whereas the Marigold is grown in abundance in the home gardens of every State of the Union;
Whereas the Marigold is grown easily and quickly from seed in every State of the Union;
Whereas the Marigold is acknowledged as a symbol of religious faith;

Whereas the Marigold in its very appearance represents not only beauty but also a rugged humility
			 of character; and

Whereas the Marigold, like the American eagle and the American flag, would be an exclusively
			 American emblem, unclaimed by any foreign country or institution: Now,
			 therefore, be it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HRES 708 IH: Expressing support for designation of September 6, 2014, as “Everett McKinley Dirksen and Marigold Day”, and designating and adopting the flower commonly known as the Marigold as the floral emblem of Congress for September 10, 2014.
